The propeller blades should have solar cells integrated so it could get rid of the solar panel, this would improve lift, since the solar panel over the blades blocks airflow, potentially would also reduce total weight, and complexity, possibly the solar cells would also stay cleaner since they move at great speed, when charging, the pitch/angle of the blades could also be adjusted to better absorb solar energy.
The underside of the blades could also have solar cells, if a simple, inflatable, reflective solar cushion was deployed under the blades that would allow them absorb reflected solar energy, improving its charge time, and so operating time, the cushion could be connected to a pulley system that would give it 2 modes, 1 deployed for solar energy charging and 1 where the pulleys would pull it down and force it to wrap around the batteries to further protect it from the low temperatures, reducing battery charge needed to maintain the batteries alive.

I would have asked a couple of additional questions...

1. What are some of the future directions that this technology may be taken? Having a design that closes is a feat of ingenuity, having a design that scales down for multiple drones seems like a new worthwhile goal for the next generation design. The heating problem seems like an obvious new direction to explore - two thirds of the battery needed for heating seems like a big price to pay. With less battery required one might consider flying a more sophisticated payload (hyperspectral, lidar, or other exotic sensors). A rover with the task of keeping drones warm seems like it belongs in the trade space.
2. Even though there is a 20 minute control delay, what are some strategies to overcome this obstacle? Having multiple autonomous flights with each successive flight using information from previous flights seems like one obvious strategy. Having a fully autonomous "explore mode" that attempts to see terrain from multiple angles so that high fidelity 3D reconstruction can be done and used for detailed analyses and successive flights. The trade space here seems large and open for new innovations that would have applications here on earth.

Great video, it was very cool to see and hear the creators of Ingenuity!

But I really wish you would not have said that "on Earth helicopters spin their blades at 500 rpm" (to contrast it with how fast Ingenuity's blades spin 1:45). It is indeed a very intuitive thing to say that Ingenuity flies in the thin atmosphere of Mars "because its blades spin crazy fast" but the reality is much more subtle.

The helicopters on Earth spin their blades in a very wide range of rpm, depending on the size of the helicopter -- from below 200 rpm for the large full size helicopters, to 8000 rpm for DJI drones. If we compare Ingenuity to the RC helicopters of equal size, we would see much more similar rpm. RC helicopters with the rotors of the same 1.2 meter diameter as ingenuity (550 or 570 class) spin their blades at 2000-2500 rpm and even faster for some aerobatic flying.

This does not, of course mean that Ingenuity is just another off-the shelf RC helicopter -- or course it is different in many parameters! But even though it seems counter-intuitive, the rpm is not one of these differences that make it fly on Mars.

It would be more meaningful to say that the very wide and specialized rotor blades of Ingenuity could lift it on Earth with just 500 rpm (if it had sufficient torque, strength etc). Then, 2500 rpm on Mars is indeed very fast in comparison.

This is all very interesting as I understood there was little or no atmosphere on Mars. We all know that any form of air transportation is impossible aside from sending a rocket into space, which once it leaves the earths atmosphere is not exactly flying but only in a basically stable trajectory toward some other place. It must rely on gravity to change direction once it has left the outer layer of earths atmosphere for the most part. So it confounds me how a drone such as this is going to fly up there. There must be enough atmosphere around Mars to allow this. I haven't followed or studied what is happening out there so I don't know much other than what I read not long ago about the planet actually having a very thin atmosphere of something. The only way a conventional rocket will function is if there is something for the engine to propel against, such as expanded gases or solid objects, the solid object as in the surface of the Moon during the Lunar missions. Calculating the diameter of the blades:

# Assuming Mach 0.7 at 2,900rpm:
# 870kph (Mach 1 on Mars) x 0.7 = 609kph
# = 10,150 meters per minute
# 1 revolution = 10,150/2,900 = 3.5m
# Diameter = 3.5m / Pi = 1.1m

The reason why quad copters are cheaper and more plentiful to hobbyists is that all that complexity and related reliability/stress is eliminated. Flight requirements are more easily sent to the multiple motors rather than geared and levered in precise co-ordination with the rotation.
If counter rotating props are desirable, you can do that with a quadcopter design also, but at least on a hobbiyst scale of typically 5" and 7" props hasn't been proven yet to be as beneficial as hoped. It would be interesting to know what data they developed to support counter rotating props, it's not seen often in modern full scale helicopters, too. Would be different if props were ducted...

Why not using a quad-copter (Drone) , is more stable and simpler mechanically. I'm not even sure how it can maneuver easily front, back, left or right without a tail rotor. The high rpm is not what counts . The tip speed to speed of sound ratio( tip mach No) should not exceed 0.85
the speed of sound depends on temperature and composition of the atmosphere.
The speed of sound is close to 240 meters/second. So 2800 rpm is a reasonable value.
The required power to hover a counter rotating helicopter is
P=(w×0.38)^1.5 /D
×√(2/π/den) ×1/fm
w = weight on earth
D = rotor diameter
den = 0.0153 kg/m^3
density
π = 3.1416..
fm = 0.4 = figure of merit for a coaxial rotor
Units are: w in newtons
power in watts
D in meters
In forward flight for a well streamlined fuselage the power is reduced, but for this cubic shape not much.
10% increase in weight
requires a 15% increase in power required.
10% increase in rotor diameter reduces power by 10%
10% reduction in density increases power required only by 5%
A tandem rotor configuration is much better. the figure of merit is higher, 0.6
That in a nutshell is the physics

The mars helicopter knows where it is at all times.





It knows this because it knows where it isn't.
By subtracting where it is from where it isn't,
Or where it isn't from where it is (whichever is
Greater), it obtains a difference, or deviation.
The guidance subsystem uses deviations to generate corrective
Commands to drive the mars helicopter from a position where it is to a
Position where it isn't,
And arriving at a position where it wasn't, it now is.
Consequently, the position where it is,
Is now the position that it wasn't,
And it follows that the position that
It was, is now the position that it isn't.
In the event that the position that it is in is not the position that
It wasn't, the system has acquired a variation,
The variation being the difference between
Where the mars helicopter is, and where it wasn't.
If variation is considered to be a
Significant factor, it too may be corrected by the GEA.
However, the mars helicopter must also know where it was.
The mars helicopter guidance computer scenario works as follows.
Because a variation has modified some of the information
The mars helicopter has obtained, it is not sure just where it is.
However, it is sure where it isn't,
Within reason, and it knows where it was.
It now subtracts where it should be from where it wasn't,
Or vice-versa, and by differentiating this from the algebraic sum of
Where it shouldn't be, and where it was,
It is able to obtain the deviation
And its variation, which is called error.

Notice something...when Chief Engineer Dr. Balaram (black T-shirt, Ph. D., Computer and Systems Engineering, Rensselaer, 1985) speaks, he is SO conversant with the topic, the engineering specifics, the background Science and the planetary characteristics that he never falters, never searches for a word, he just lays out the info bam bam bam. Also, notice, when he was talking about the function of a helicopter's collective and cyclic, a layman would have said it provides 'tilt' , BUT which is a RESULT.
Dr. Balaram uses the term 'asymmetric torque' , which is what the cyclic actually creates. THIS then CAUSES the helicopter to tilt and thus the 'copter experiences lateral movement (result).
I used to tell my students how important accuracy of language was when speaking of technical matters, especially cause/effect situations, and this was an excellent example. Had I not recently retired, I would be sure to use this vid, as I have many other Veritasium vids, in my class.
I also would have pointed out that Project MANAGER Mimi Aung proves once again that GIRLS CAN DO SCIENCE!! In my classroom, I had a print made of a screenshot from the fantastic (and very moving) video "Margaret by Moonlight" and a blowup of a photo of her (Margaret Hamilton) standing next to the STACK of software which was written by the team which SHE LED, back in the 60s. I see a real purpose in building this helicopter.  This is obviously an out of the park custom project that has technology trickle-down data written all over it.  I can think of an example of this in another industry, I think of MotoGP racing, the premier motorcycle racing event worldwide.  The machines are constantly evolving with new technology, very expensive at that level.  At one time any technological advantages were closely guarded secrets, but over time things became more transparent, I suppose the motorcycle manufacturers realized the buying public eats up these advances once they were applied to bikes sold in the retail market, they now incorporate a lot of the technology developed in MotoGP.  I own a special Ducati motorcycle, the 999R model built in 2003,  even with the  "R" designation, meaning it qualified as a race homologation bike under World Superbike rules, having higher-spec upgrades, but it did not have the extensive electronic safety and riding aids that are now common on motorcycles today, It is amazing what the electronic packages contain on higher-end, or even mid-level motorcycles today, stuff that was unheard of not many years ago.

The scientific methodology from this is we should learn what engineering techniques worked & what did not. We >should< be able to fly in a number of differing atmospheres... the question is what lessons do we learn in our failed attempts and how do we progress? ... They said it ran noisy.  Noise = inefficiency.  Also, it looked like the lower blade profile matched the upper one, this is not optimal, the lower blade needs a bigger leading edge attack angle since it meets a flow established by the upper props.  Also, the blades should have a skewed (curved, non-linear) top view profile which will smooth out vibrations since for a straight blade, the entire length of the lower blade smacks into the primary flow coming off the trailing edge of the upper prop blade (this is the main source of the buzzing noise they heard).  Also, the prop tips need tiplets like you see on airplane wings.  The tiplets significantly reduce the spilling over the tip edge as the high pressure side tries to get to the low pressure side which helps prevent the creation of the vortex coming off the trailing edge of a no-tiplet blade.  Tiplets will also increase the thrust efficiency by 5% to 10%.

During take-offs, the surface beneath the drone will be exposed to more atmospheric flow than it has EVER experienced. If the resulting dust cloud persists for more than 90 seconds in the landing area, the images, and the real-time self-navigation data, may be less informative than say, the pristine floor of a hypobaric clean room. It's nice that environmental "wind" on Mars is trivial, but the drone has to generate enough thrust to lift 1.8 kg. I see dust. Lots of sharp, fresh dust, meeting blade tips moving at mach 0.7, settling very slowly, with little fishing lines suspending every particle. I'm sure it's been considered, but the interview could have been a little meatier.

A quibble: Dr. Balaram mentions a "compactified flow" produced of the tandem arrangement of the upper helicopter blade. This is simply not so. The lower blade is made significantly more efficient in the flow field produced by the upper blade because it "de-swirls" the flow. Lowered pressure induced of velocity increase, induced swirl, and centrifugal force will do just the opposite of "concentrating" it.

There is a mystery here. If two-thirds of its available power is used for heating, as you say, why were the two motors not integrated into the suspended battery and electronics pack? Dr. Aung's implied statement that "Aerogel is too heavy" is utterly silly, especially in this context. A cubic decimeter, weighing only 20 g, would have been more than sufficient to serve as insulation to keep in the heat emitted from two operating internally-mounted motors, and combined with preheating from the Perseverance itself, would have allowed all battery power to be dedicated to flight, increasing its flight time by thrice and/or providing a significantly increased margin of safety to account for battery aging. Only 40 Whr seems to be "uncomfortably" minimal when taking into account battery aging and decreased performance when exposed to the harsh ongoing environmental conditions -- both during and between flights.

There is no redesigning the craft now, but I am doubly curious to know what the engineering rationale is for its current design.

I sure hope that Perseverance is programmed to store (and deploy) Ingenuity from its base -- just in case Intrepid's power runs out, it can land, and Perseverance can theoretically travel to it and recover (and recharge) it.

The above, or else a hook or other grappling mount, that having landed, will allow Perseverance's arm to easily pick it up. I don't spot one. Is it actually expected that it necessarily land atop Perseverance to be recovered?

Is there provision to clean and/or keep clean the aerodynamic surfaces when the inevitable dust storm will coat them in Martian dust? A dirty surface will significantly decrease aerodynamic efficiency, and therefore thrust and/or duration of flight. Electrostatic attraction will not allow mere rotation to blow the dust off completely. A thin coating of Teflon would, I think, not have increased weight unduly....

I'm having trouble making an educated "guesstimate" of the applicable Reynolds Number. Are you aware that under a certain value, a roughened wing surface is more aerodynamically efficient than a smooth one? Those wings look to have a gloss finish....

Also, Martian surface radiation was responsible for making effectively inoperative one of the two onboard hardened motherboards aboard Curiosity -- costing a quarter of a million dollars. I sure hope that not only is this rectified on Perseverance, but also on its drone which is "all but unflyable by a human pilot."

You know, merely mounting the (two) motherboards about Curiosity/Perseverance vertically, not horizontally, will significantly decrease exposure from solar radiation. Is this indeed applicable?

Oh, Veritasium: 85kft is the maximum altitude of horizontal, controlled powered flight, but zoom climbs of military jets have easily much exceeded 100kft.

The Mars helicopter will fail and this is why.
The softball-sized "marscopter" weighs about four pounds and is fitted with two sets of rotor blades, which can spin at 3000 rotations a minute. Too much technology and the lack of endurance is what I’m basing my option on.
I may not be a “rocket engineer” but I have worked in the world of mechanical engineering over many, many years.
NASA’s little helicopter is the size of softball This "marscopter" weighs about four pounds and is fitted with two sets of rotor blades, which can spin at 3000 rotations a minute and as a drone will have to land no matter what batteries or power supplies it has. Yes I did see that NASA/JPL did design a rotor blade assembly incorporating the use of photovoltaics The possibility of damage to either rotor blades is of high risk. If the rotor or motor should fail because of the abrasion of fine particulates in the Martian atmosphere it will become immobile. Also there is one more point that makes this impractical is wind. (Gravity still works just as well on Mars as it does on Earth)
Given that Mars has only 0.7% of atmospheric pressure of the Earth, the rotor blades would be of such a size it would be an impractical design (Most helicopters can fly up to 25000ft at its maximum. A black hawk can fly up to 10000ft. Indian Chetak Helis can fly up to 20000ft but remember your dealing with Earth not Mars.)
Now I would use an older technology and that is a powered airship. Yes a lighter than aircraft! It will carry a heaver payload than any helicopter you could ever launch from the surface of Mars.
If the motor failed on it would not crash and its payload will keep functioning. Although it would be at the mercy of the winds on Mars. (The wind speeds that Viking observed at its site in summer is 2 to 7 m/s (5 to 16 mph) The wind speeds at Viking site in fall is 5 to 10 m/s (11 to 22 mph) and the wind speeds at Viking site in a dust storm 17 to 30 m/s (38 to 67 mph). At higher altitudes, the movement of dust was measured at 250-300 mph. This may sound fast but you have to realize that weather balloons on Earth frequently traverse the jet streams without harm.)
A lighter than airship can be made buoyant neutral and gather samples from a wide range without difficulty and return to its base following a homing beacon and dock. This base could also be used as a return vehicle and return samples to Earth if needed. The docking station could use an electromagnet on a swivel as to face into any winds when docked It could also use the photovoltaics on the top of this airship to supplement power at the docking base for running tests on any samples retrieved and download photos or videos for transmission back to Earth.

Bro... it's not going to fly on Mars... and why would anyone want to go there?... it's been a solid lump, basically, since it cooled down.. it doesn't have a semi molten mantle and solid core.. it's just solid, so no electromagnetic field protecting the surface... it's a requirement for life on the surface of a planet... the atmosphere is a very tenuous thing... from chemical reactions in the dust of the surface and the rock underneath... despite much advertising to the contrary, there's never been life on Mars. No atmosphere to speak of means heat is not retained... Mars is NOT in the goldilocks zone... it's never been in the goldilocks zone... some boyo at NASA told me that the sun was hotter in the past... is that true do you think?... it's not.. our sun is a very very normal main sequence star... and the 3rd Planet is in the goldilocks zone... and we call it main sequence because a majority of stars in our galaxy and in all nearby galaxies are very very similar, with similar spectrum... it's not magic... it's the way "stuff " fits together...

I wonder if the lower gravity has any weird effects on flight dynamics? Removing the mass to simulate Martian weight only solves half the problem. Remember the feather and hammer test on the moon? They fall at the same rate but slower than earth. So on Mars the helicopter won't fall as fast as on earth. The only way to simulate that would be in a parabolic plane flight.

It might not really affect the flight computer, but I am curious if it does have any odd effects, and it's something very hard to test on earth outside of computer modelling.

2700 rpm is what a Cessna 172 spins it prop. What limits the rpm is the efficiency and cavitation plus the speed of sound. In our atmosphere at standard temperature and pressure, a 60 inch propeller can only spin at 4K rpm before the tip speed exceeds the props efficacy at the tips. 880 FPS  tip speed, is the max, if my memory serves. When that limit is reached, the prop gets very loud and the aircraft would actually accelerate if the rpm is decreased.

"NASA did not design the Mars 2020 mission or Perseverance rover around the Mars Helicopter, but it’s making the trip nonetheless. The helicopter is a technology demonstration, not an integral part of the mission. However, it could pave the way for future flying endeavors on Mars. The team has already confirmed that the helicopter should be able to fly in the thin Martian atmosphere thanks to its ultra-light design and the planet’s lower gravity. 

The last flight test took place about a year ago (see below), and the helicopter still hasn’t lifted off again — it’s tuned for the Martian atmosphere, so any flights on Earth require extensive preparation to avoid damaging the machinery. However, the team did conduct one more vital test of the rotors last week in the Payload Hazardous Servicing Facility. 

Engineers ran the Mars Helicopter rotors at 50 RPM on a static test stand, which is much slower than they’ll rotate on Mars. The planet’s thin atmosphere means even a light craft like the four-pound helicopter needs a very high rate of rotation to generate lift. The design allows for up to 2,800 revolutions per minute, but it should be able to lift off at around 1,900 RPM. The JPL test confirms the motor is working as intended, and the helicopter is ready to be mounted on the underside of the Perseverance rover. 

Despite the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, NASA has worked to keep the Mars 2020 mission on-schedule. Work has stopped on the James Webb Space Telescope for now, but the clock is ticking for the rover. If it doesn’t launch as planned this summer, NASA will have to wait another two years for Earth and Mars to be aligned again. 

If all goes as planned, Perseverance will launch July 17 and touch down on Mars in February 2021. It will deploy the helicopter, which has its own solar power system and camera. It will communicate with Perseverance wirelessly via the ZigBee radio protocol. Image data from the helicopter might help Perseverance navigate the challenging terrain of Mars, but future flying drones could be much more integral to exploring Mars."

Quadcopters are actually much simpler than coaxial copters (like the mars helicopter), mechanically. Quadcopters don't need a complicated swashplate or variable pitch mechanism on their blades to navigate--they just speed up or slow down the rotation of their propellers. Thing is, they're much less efficient than a coaxial copter because their blades are smaller. The larger a propeller at hover, the more efficient it is, which is likely why the engineers at JPL went for a coaxial copter.

---a story by a child who lost his desire  to become a scientist - I WAS ONLY 10 IN THE 80'S, MY PARENTS BOUGHT ME A ROBOT, THAT JUST HAD A NUMBER PAD. THE ROBOT WOULD GO WHATEVER FEET I SPECIFIED, TURN A SPECIFIED DEGREE AND SEARCH AREAS BASED ON MY INSTRUCTIONS. IT WAS SO COOL TO WATCH. BUT AS A TEN YEAR OLD, THEY HAD NO CAMERAS OR AVOIDANCE SENSORS and, of course, no GPS.. I WAS IMPRESSED WITH IT. BUT ONE DAY WE WENT ON VACATION FOR ONE OR 2 WEEKS. WHILE WE WERE GONE , SOMEHOW, THE PILOT LIGHT IN OUR OIL HEATER FLAMED OUT. THE HOUSE , THE OIL, AND THE WATER IN THE PIPES FROZE. THE WATER  EXPANDED, CRACKING THE PIPES, THUS,  FLOODING THE HOUSE.  THE UNFROZEN WATER FLOWED EVERYWHERE, TURNING THE HOUSE INTO A DISNEY MOVIE,  "ICE QUEEN" OR  "FROZEN" . MY  LITTLE ROBOT WAS IN THE BASEMENT ON THE POOL TABLE, THE WATER PIPES EXPLODED ONTO IT AND FROZE EVERTHING IN ICE. EVERYTHING CRACKED , RIPPED APART, OR SHATTERED. IT WAS ONE OF THE WORST DAYS OF MY FAMILIE'S LIFE. I TRIED TO FIND ANOTHER ROBOT LIKE THAT ONE, BUT THEY DISCONTINUED MAKING THEM. SADDEST DAY OF MY LIFE. IT WAS LIKE HAVING MY OWN NASA ROBOT, ONLY I KNEW THE CODES TO ENTER INSTRUCTIONS. I CRIED FOR MONTHS (REMEMBER I WAS ONLY 9 OR 10).

From the XF-84H wiki ; "The XF-84H was almost certainly the loudest aircraft ever built, earning the nickname "Thunderscreech" as well as the "Mighty Ear Banger". On the ground "run ups", the prototypes could reportedly be heard 25 miles (40 km) away. Unlike standard propellers that turn at subsonic speeds, the outer 24–30 inches (61–76 cm) of the blades on the XF-84H's propeller traveled faster than the speed of sound even at idle thrust, producing a continuous visible sonic boom that radiated laterally from the propellers for hundreds of yards. The shock wave was actually powerful enough to knock a man down; an unfortunate crew chief who was inside a nearby C-47 was severely incapacitated during a 30-minute ground run. Coupled with the already considerable noise from the subsonic aspect of the propeller and the T40's dual turbine sections, the aircraft was notorious for inducing severe nausea and headaches among ground crews. In one report, a Republic engineer suffered a seizure after close range exposure to the shock waves emanating from a powered-up XF-84H."

Lin Hendrix, one of the Republic test pilots assigned to the program, flew the aircraft once and refused to ever fly it again - he told the formidable Republic project engineer, "You aren't big enough and there aren't enough of you to get me in that thing again".

When they mentioned the speed of sound limit for the tips of the blades I thought it couldn’t possibly be a problem in an atmosphere of just 1% density, but oh how wrong can first impression be. The speed is actually even lower than on Earth, due to a mind blowing complexity of variables explained here: https://www.quora.com/What-is-the-speed-of-sound-on-Mars/answer/Phil-Karn?ch=10&share=b84e4b5a&srid=h6xDE

Mars atmosphere has pressure of 6.1 mBar. This means the drone engine has to make 163.9  times more rotation speed to get equivalent lift in the Earth gravity. Mars gravity is 3.711, it is 2.642 times less than times less than Earth gravity, so we need 163.9/2.642 = 62 times more rotation speed for the motor. How do they achieve that?

Many years ago at a Space based lecture/conference in Pasadena there was a proposed drone airplane for a Mars mission on display. I was amazed that anyone would design a airfoil capable of flying on Mars. One question I was surprised you did not ask in the video was "Why a helicopter?"


But you did answer the question for me, sort of. Helicopters are less efficient as aircraft, as your graphic on aircraft records shows, but the testing facilities for a fixed wing machine here on earth do not exist. The largest vacuum chambers NASA has are all more vertical than horizontal so of course it makes sense to see if the helicopter can be made, but more important reason, I would guess, is that without flying fields to land safely on Mars such a winged aircraft could only be launched just once, instead of once per Martian day.

I have to believe a glider configuration is better.  The downside of that is the need for a relatively flat area for take-off roll and landing roll.  However, the craft could be spring launched and a drag surface could shorten landing roll dramatically.  This is more complex, but the inefficiencies of flying in such thin air give the glider configuration enormous advantages.  This is probably a case where the current popularity of drones influenced the decision and tipped the balance.  But I'm betting in the future a glider configuration will become the norm.

Basically helis like this have 6 axis stabilization using PID loops. They are stabilized for roll, pitch, yaw, but also for vertical, both horizontal planes so that it can stay perfectly still in all 3 dimensions even with wind, instability, etc. It sounds like they are using camera assisted tracking as well, to help it guide itself (no GPS on Mars) and probably a lidar altimeter. I was a little surprised they are using foam core blades because of the low air pressure. The slightest crack or flaw in the carbon fiber, and those blades will expand like styrofoam in a vacuum chamber. Helicopters are fragile, and on the ground they are susceptible to wind. Those will be challenges on Mars due to high velocity wind, dust devils, and dust storms.

Comparing the rotor rpm to an average manned helicopter is not very useful, as the rotor diameter is the most important factor in determining the useful rpm.

The speed of the tip of the blade is what matters, so the longer the blade, the less rpm you need. My 700 size RC helicopter has a rotor diameter of about 160 cm and I mostly fly at 2100 rpm, though it can easily do 2500.

On the other hand, some of the biggest manned helicopters in the world run less than 100 rpm.

Gravity on Mars is 38% of Earth's gravity. If it's 100lbs on Earth, it would only be 38lbs on Mars.
Turn on subtitles at 6:10

The whole flight on Mars thing is really complicated. Weighing less on the planet means you don't have to generate as much lift which is great since the atmosphere is so thin. The problem is that you still have the same inertial mass so trying to maneuver by pushing control surfaces through that air (as opposed to using thrusters) is much, much harder. The blades have to spin really fast to provide enough control more than they have to spin to provide lift.

Accelerometers work by putting out a voltage based on the amount of G on the X, Y, Z axis. G'day,

Very interesting.

Thanks for making & posting this.

One point which you bent out of shape, turning it into Hyperbolic Marketing Jism though, was the assertion to the effect that,
"Because the Atmosphere on Mars is so thin, they have to spin the Rotors SIX TIMES Faster than the ones on a "Normal" Heligoflopter, here on Earth...!"

Illustrated by a shot of a Robinson R-44 which has a 30-odd ft diameter Rotor Disc twirling at 300 RPM.... ; but if you'd looked at a Hughes 300c or 500 - or their McDonnel Douglas derivitaves, they run 20-something ft diameter Rotors, with 3 & 5 Blades, and with 3 & 5 Passengers they rotate their Arrays at 500 RPM...

Reducing the DIAMETER permits the RPM to be increased while maintaining 500 MPH Tip-Speed (Mach 0.7) for maximum Aerodynamic Efficiency....

And this little thing has, what.., 5 ft, or is it 6 Ft Rotor Diameter (?) ; that's about the size of a big R/C Model Heligoflopter used for "3-D" Aerobatic Display/Competitions, using either Glowplug or Electric Motors...; and LOTS of them run their Rotors at around 2,000 RPM..., as far as I know.

The first R/C model Electric Helicopter I ever had used a 1-ft diameter Co-Axial Contra-Rotating Rotor Array, with 2 Motors, for differential Yaw & Collective (go faster to go up..) Control, and a Pitch-Control Rotor on the Tail...all made in China, and sold in Oz for $100, and it had NO Autopilot at all, not even a Gyroscopic "Heading-Hold with Manual Over-Ride" on the Yaw-Stick...

It took me a solid month to learn to fly it, only ever at Dawn, in ZERO Wind, but if you title-search my Videos for,

"R/C Model Helicopter Test Flight..."

therein you may see (Potato-grade) headcamera footage of it taking off from a 5-ft by 7-ft Pad, flying out 50 metres & back in a big Figure-8..., and then landing back on the Pad (!).

I wasn't goanna let it beat me, y'see.

So, perhaps y'alls should've tried harder for longer, because I learned a lot about Co-Ax. Rotors by flying one manually...

The most pertinent nugget of wisdom is that they are VERY susceptable to Rotor Decay when trying to descend through their own Downwash..., so I learned to fly it with Forward Airspeed ALWAYS, except when lifting off..., I made running landings rather than risk stopping when 10 ft up and trying to slowly come down Vertically.

This Marscopter cannot make a running-landing.., so my advice is to allocate 20 seconds to ascend, 10 seconds to hover & look around..., then 30 seconds to descend to a Hover 1 ft above the Selected next Landing - 5 seconds to settle onto the Ground..., and that leaves 25 seconds for contingencies and being nice to the Battery by not using ALL of what it theoretically has to give..(?) !

There's an Englishman running a YT Channel (+TBOBORAP Ch.) which is devoted to very high grade Videography of large RC Models doing their stuff at low level..., he has many Videos posted showing contemporary High-Tech R/C Model Rotary-Wing Toys...

Check it out, and try not to go comparing Model Helicopter Rotor Array operating RPM with Human-Crewed Helicopter RPM..., it's not really a valid comparison because the frame of reference is wrong....; the Marscopter's Rotor RPM is 6 times faster than that of the R-44, because the R-44's Rotor is 6 times the Diameter of the Marscopter....

Here's a general monofilament 'fishing line' tip. Use swivels. They're called inline barrel swivels, higher quality are ball bearing swivels. I make my own mobiles, they hang from 'fishing line' that's attached to the ceiling. Without the swivels the line lasts about a year, then snaps, it starts getting kinks within a month. With a swivel it works much better because it doesn't 'wind up,' and the line lasts much longer. With a swivel? So far ten years no problem.

Very exciting. One thing that was a bit misleading is that the 2,900 rpm of this drone’s rotor were compared to the 500 rpm of the main rotor of a full-scale manned helicopter. RC model helicopters do have typical rotor rpms around 2,000 to 3,500 rpm, for example the T-Rex 500 with a rotor diameter of almost 100 cm has a maximum rpm of 3,200. The blade tip speed reaches 600 kph, which is just under half the speed of sound on Earth. The difference is that the blades of the Mars drone are much wider and thus have a much larger surface, and there are two coaxial main rotors, which doubles lift again.

Honestly, I'm now a skeptic of this project's value...at this time.  Upon hearing about this project, I was like "YES! It's about time!", but after listening to the figures for weight vs flight time, I don't see how this project, for right now anyhow, with the materials we have to use in 2019, has spending tax payer money making any sense.  It's not scalable.  Again, using the materials we have available today, if you want a longer flight, you need more battery charge capacity.  In order to have the same vehicle fly for 3 minutes, you would need twice the batteries.  Twice the batteries means twice the weight and twice the interior volume of the fuselage.  More weight equals more disk surface (longer rotor blades).  Basically, the usable payload will remain what it is for the smaller craft.  Or am I missing something?  Once the initial study was concluded and they determined a craft of this size and weight might be able to fly for 90 seconds, the review board should have shelved the project for 15 to 20 years until either battery or composite material technology (or both) had matured a bit.

While I'm all for a demonstration of flight on mars as a mental flex, I do think that a rover that actually moves with actual instruments can be the superior explorer. If able to move at 10-15km/h autonomously and fast sensors able to scratch the dirt and do instant composition, you can explore vast distances on mars over a year or two. In the first afternoon it will vastly eclipse the pathetic rovers that came before and over a year it could reasonably cover all near surface aspects of mars. A decently engineered rover could also have the capability for the occasional 2 meter drilling into the ground. Not to miss any aquifer gems just below the surface.

So, the explosions to the bolts they are talking about are actually a common thing on aircraft. Munitions and fuel tanks are released and jettisoned, using the same technology. They're little cylinder looking things called carts, or squibs. They also move the items being released far enough away from the aircraft so the items don't hit the wings etc. when release happens. Ejection seats work a bit like this as well, only the explosive items for these are called CADS and PADS.

Curious. Doesn't the density (or lack thereof) of the atmosphere  on Mars affect what is determined to be the speed of sound? On Earth, for example, all of those who watched the Bonneville Salt Flats speed-record attempts of the 60's remember that the speed of sound at sea level was about 761 mph.
